factoid: The princess told the count vile and disgraceful things about the narrator and Sophie.
The princess's allegations made the count ill.
The count did not see the narrator and Sophie for a whole fortnight.
The count wrote a vile, infamous paper after the princess's allegations.
The narrator believes the paper is invalid.
The princess says the inlaid portfolio that the count keeps under his pillow contains the paper.
The princess hates the vile woman Sophie.
The princess says she will give Sophie a piece of her mind.
A carriage carrying Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna arrived at Count Bezúkhov's house.
Pierre had been sent for by the count.
Anna Mikháylovna accompanied Pierre to the carriage.
Anna Mikháylovna woke Pierre because he was asleep.
Pierre and Anna left the carriage together.
Pierre was going to interview his dying father.
They entered Count Bezúkhov's house through the back door.
Two men who looked like tradespeople hid in the shadow of the wall near the entrance.
Pierre noticed several other men of the same kind hiding on both sides of the wall.
Anna Mikháylovna and the footman did not notice those men.
Pierre concluded it seemed all right and followed Anna.
Anna ascended the narrow dimly lit stone staircase.
Pierre lagged behind Anna on the staircase.
Pierre did not understand why he had to go to the count or by the back stairs.
Men carrying pails ran down the stairs, pressing close to the wall to let Pierre and Anna pass.
The men did not show surprise at seeing Pierre and Anna.
Anna asked one of the men if this was the way to the princesses' apartments.
A footman answered that the door to the left was the way to the princesses' apartments.
Pierre said he might not have been asked by the count.
Pierre decided to go to his own room.
Anna paused and waited for Pierre to come up.
Anna told Pierre that she suffers no less than he does but told him to be a man.
Anna said she loved Pierre like a son from the first.
Anna told Pierre to trust himself to her.
Anna said she would not forget Pierre's interests.
Pierre followed Anna to open a door.
